title: Introducing: Explicits
content:
Initially I couldn’t find out too much about Explicits, aside from the fact that they are from Detroit and have a love of sultry, black and white images. However, after a considerable amount of digging, I discovered that Explicits is the new project of 800beloved main man Sean Lynch. Having released a minute long teaser video entitled revoL (Lover spelled backwards) just under five months ago, featuring a downbeat, instrumental track and flashing imagery, it’s bizarre that the hype hasn’t quite built up to higher levels.

Another grainy black and white video followed three months later, this time entitled Lover, and showing who I assume is Lynch, performing a subdued acoustic number. Atmospheric and seductive, the track itself is Joy Division-esque in nature, brooding and remorseful, proving wonderfully exposed.

Lover from Explicits on Vimeo.

With the year drawing to a close, Explicits have made two new cuts available via their bandcamp page as well as the full version of revoL. Released under the title The Uncanny Valley, it’s unclear as to whether this will form a full release or an EP which will be Lynch’s debut full length release under the Explicits moniker.. The entirely instrumental RAM serves well as an opening track, drawling and languid, providing a stable platform for what’s to come. In fact, whilst writing this article I noticed that revoL was added to the bandcamp page, and it’s a stunning ambient inspired number, with the vocals playing a pivotal role alongside the sampled female spoken word sections.

As I begin to compile end of year lists, it’s showing me that it’s going to take something special to muscle it’s way into my final choices, and US may well do just that. Again, there’s a real late 70’s feel to the track, with it’s unique brand of emotional downbeat pop. The vocals are smooth and harrowing at times, as are the poignant lyrics, “baby we should drive away, where no one will find us“. To be honest, I’m still coming to terms with just how sublime this track is, with it’s raw power and pure elegant simplicity. Check out US below, and stay tuned for updates on what is sure to be a bright future for Explicits and Sean Lynch.
